head.supplied: ¶ […] ¶ ¶ Anyhow I shall forward specimens of those trees to Baron von Muller at the same time [now] and have them determined. ... Since I am aware of the error [Cabbage Gum = E ¶ ¶ Sieberiana], ...

div.p: MRS 203, Inwards correspondence — special bundles, 1886-1921 Item 1, 89/237, Archives of the Powerhouse Museum, Sydney.

Anyhow I shall forward specimens of those trees to Baron von Muller at the same time [now] and have them determined. ... Since I am aware of the error [Cabbage Gum = E Sieberiana], it has always been a puzzle to me how it may have occurred, the more so when on reference to my notes I found that it was really the material of the "Cabbage Gum" which Baron von Muller had determined for me as E. Sieberiana. . […] I think it was in 1884 I sent specimens of the "Cabbage Gum" to Baron von Muller to have them determined for me. At that time I hardly knew anything of the Flora of Australia, having then only collected and studied the Ferns, so it is quite possible that then I sent the specimens without any further notes as to bark and general appearance of the tree. When we consider that E. pauciflora varies considerably in size and shape of bud and fruit and that the young material is also somewhat alike, then it may be quite possible, especially if the specimen sent should have been somewhat abnormal, that Baron von Muller was misled in his determination. You will remember that we had a similar, and in the present state of the inquiry, significant instance in the case of the hybrid from the Delegate River, which Baron von Muller at the time determined to be E. amygdalina var . In that instance it is hardly possible that the Baron can have read the notes accompanying the specimens.

Now I would draw your attention to the fact that in the Braidwood district on similar poor and stony mountain ranges occurs a tree quite similar in appearance and there also called: "Mountain Ash" and "Whitetopped Iron Bark". Of this tree you recieved
sic.
a log (Nro. 101) from Monga in January of the present year, under the name of Euc. amygdalina var . as determined for me by Baron von Muller some years ago. Some time ago I mentioned to you that I had doubts about this tree being a variety of E. amygdalina, in consequence of which I sent a second complete set of specimens to the Baron in order to have it determined again, but up to date I have recieved no determination yet. At this moment I can only speak from memory, but I am almost sure that the leaves and fruit of the tree from Monga (Log Nro. 101) are quite different from the present species E. Sieberiana, which would to some extent as E. amygdalina var . […]
Not relevant.
